DOC.HEAD: Half of GM's Linden Plant Shutting Down Indefinitely in February
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. is eliminating one of two shifts at a New Jersey car assembly plant, adding to the production woes of the nation's auto industry. On Thursday, GM spokesman Phil Workman in Lansing said the second shift at the automaker's Linden plant would stop production Feb. 26 and about 1,600 workers would be laid off indefinitely. The first shift will continue producing Chevrolet Corsica and Beretta automobiles. Also on Thursday, GM and Chrysler Corp. added to their lists of factories temporarily suspending production in January. That brings to 42 of the Big Three's 53 U.S. assembly plants which will be down for at least one week each next month. More than 127,000 workers will be affected. In addition to state unemployment benefits, laid-off workers can draw on special funds that can boost their pay during factory shutdowns to as much as 95 percent of their straight-time wages. The effect of the shutdowns on the country's auto industry supply community is difficult to measure, and it's likely that thousands of other workers could face temporary layoffs next month. All the assembly plant closings are caused by slumping sales and high new-vehicle inventories. Demand for Corsica and Beretta cars, which are also produced in Wilmington, Del., has been slipping. Sales this year through Dec. 10 were 12.7 percent behind last year's pace. GM's domestic car sales, meantime, were off 8.3 percent for the same time. Combined inventory of the two cars _ essentially the same except Beretta has two doors and Corsica has four _ stood at 123 days at the end of November, based on the current selling pace according to Ward's Automotive Reports, a weekly industry newsletter. Inventory for the eight major U.S. automakers stood at 88 days, Ward's said. News of the Linden shutdown hit workers hard. ``It's no Merry Christmas when a person has been trying to dig in with the company, working twice as hard, working with the management, trying to sell the cars ourselves, putting our heart into it,'' said United Auto Workers union Local 595 President Charlie Marshall. ``To hear there's only one shift is a big letdown for everybody,'' he added. ``We all feel like we've been had.''
